content.text:
# Draft:Enoch George Howard

* Enoch Howard should link here
Enoch George Howard (1814–1895) was an American landowner and African American community leader in Maryland. He had been enslaved and was freed in 1850. Howard petitioned the Montgomery County government to provide land and build schools to educate African American students. By 1870, Montgomery County granted the request. Howard owned almost  of land.
He married Harriet Lee (1808–1882), and they had four children. Howard lived in a house located at what is now called the Gaither–Howard houses historic site. The site and some of his landholdings are now within the Patuxent River State Park. A historical marker on an African American history trail commemorates his family's history. It was erected by the Sandy Spring Slave Museum.
